projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE ARTICLES OF EXETER, Made on the Rendition thereof.
WITH The Vote of the Honourable Hou≈øe of Commons, in the Approbation of them of the 6. of May, 1646.

VVith the Order and Ordinance of the Lords and Commons in Parliament a≈ø≈øembled, for the Approbation, Publication, and Ob≈øervation of them, by all Committees, Judges, and Officers, and others concerned in them, of the 4. of this in≈øtant Novemb. 1647.
LONDON, Printed for John Williams, at the Crown in Saint Pauls Church-yard. 1647.

div.head: Dated at Exeter the 8. day of April, at 10. of the clock at night. 1646.

Articles of Agreement concluded on by Thomas Hammond, Lieutenant-Generall of the Ordnance, Colonel Sir Hardres Waller, Colonel Edward Harley, Colonel Lambert, Commi≈ø≈øary Generall Stane, and Major Pat≈øon, Scout-ma≈øter Generall, Commi≈øsioners on the behalf of the Right Honourable his Excellency Sir Thomas Fairfax, Generall of the Parliament Forces on the one party: And Sir Henry Berkley, Sir George Warry, Col: William A≈øhburnham, Col: Godolphin, Captain Fitz-Gerard, Ma≈øter John Were, Robert Walker E≈øq and Ma≈øter Thomas Knot Merchant, Commi≈øsioners on the behalfe of Sir John Berkley, Knight, Governour of the City of Exeter on the other party, touching and concerning the Rendition of the ≈øaid City and Garri≈øon as followeth.
div.p:
1. THat the City and Garri≈øon of Exeter, together with the Ca≈øtle, all Forts, Mounts, and places of Defence of or belonging to the ≈øame, with all Ordnance, Armes, Ammunition, Provi≈øions and. Furniture of War belonging to the Garri≈øon, (excepting what ≈øhall be excepted in
the en≈øuing Articles) ≈øhall be delivered unto Sir Thomas Fairfax, Generall of the Parliament Forces, or to any whom he ≈øhall appoint, to receive them for the u≈øe of the Parliament, on Monday next after the date hereof, being the 13. day of this in≈øtant April, by twelve of the Clock at Noone.

2. That if any Officer, Soldier, or any per≈øon included in the≈øe Articles of or belonging unto the City or Garri≈øon of Exeter, ≈øhall after the conclu≈øion of the≈øe Articles, wrong or plunder in per≈øon or goods (in their marching away or before) any Citizen or Countryman, or any per≈øon what≈øoever, ≈øhall as far as he is able give ≈øatisfaction to the per≈øons ≈øo injured at the judgement of his Excellency Sir Thomas Fairfax, if he be not puni≈øhed before by the pre≈øent Governour thereof.

3. That if any Officer, Soldier, or any per≈øon (included in the≈øe Articles) ≈øhall after the date hereof, wilfully break, deface, ≈øpoile or imbezell any Armes, or other provi≈øions of War what≈øoever, by the precedent Articles to be ≈øurrendred as afore≈øaid, ≈øhall lo≈øe the benefit of the en≈øuing Articles.

4. That the Prince≈ø≈øe Henrietta and her Governe≈ø≈øe, with her hou≈øhold, ≈øhall have full liberty to pa≈ø≈øe with their Plate, Money, and Goods, within twenty days after the conclu≈øion of this Treaty, (when ≈øhe ≈øhall de≈øire) to any place within the Continent of England, or Dominion of Wales, at the election of the Governe≈ø≈øe, and there to remaine untill His Maje≈øties Plea≈øure be farther knowne touching her ≈øetling; And that the Governe≈ø≈øe
≈øhall have liberty to ≈øend to the King to know his Plea≈øure herein, accordingly to di≈øpo≈øe of her Highnes, within the fore≈øaid limitation of place, and that fit and convenient Carriages be provided for their pa≈ø≈øage at rea≈øonable rates.
5. That the Cathedrall Church, nor any other Church within the City ≈øhall be defaced, or any thing belonging thereunto ≈øpoiled or taken away by any Soldier or per≈øon of either ≈øide what≈øoever.

6. That the Governour, together with all Lords, Gentlemen, Clergie-men, Chaplaines, Officers, Troopers, and Common-Soldiers of the Kings Forces, ≈øhall march out of the City on Monday next the 13. of April, by twelve of the clock at noone, with their Hor≈øes, full Armes, Bag and Baggage, and their Goods, Colours flying, Drums beating, Matches lighted, Bullets, full Bandoleers, with ≈øufficient Convoyes to Oxford, or unto Hel≈øtone in Cornwall, at their ≈øeverall elections. And in ca≈øe the Governour of Oxford ≈øhall refu≈øe to receive the Common-Souldiers that ≈øhall march thither: They are there to deliver up their Armes to the Convoy, and have Pa≈ø≈øes to repaire to their ≈øeverall homes: and tho≈øe that march to Hel≈øton, are there to be disbanded, and have Pa≈ø≈øes to repaire to their owne homes. Provided that all Troopers and Common Soldiers which march not as afore≈øaid, ≈øhall deliver up their Armes, (except their Swords) and have liberty to goe unto their owne homes with Bag and Baggage, and ≈øhall not be compelled to take up Armes again≈øt the King. Provided al≈øo, that all Officers and Gentlemen that ≈øhall choo≈øe to goe
to Oxford, and not taking up Armes, ≈øhall repaire into the Parliament Quarters within forty dayes after the Date hereof, ≈øhall enjoy the benefit of the≈øe Articles.

7. That all tho≈øe which ≈øhall March unto the places afore≈øaid, ≈øhall have free Quarter in their march, and not be obliged to march above tenne miles a day, and that ≈øuch other Souldiers as are Inhabitants in the City, ≈øhall have free liberty to march out, or remaine therein, without being compelled to take up Armes again≈øt the King: And if any Souldiers ≈øhall fall ≈øick upon their march, that convenient Carriages, and Accommodations ≈øhall be provided for them.

8. That all Lords, Gentlemen, Clergymen, Chaplaines, and Officers that ≈øhall chu≈øe to goe beyond Seas, ≈øhall march away with their full Armes for their own u≈øe; and that all common Souldiers ≈øhall march away with their full Armes, with a ≈øufficient convoy unto the Port, which they ≈øhall choo≈øe for their tran≈øportation, which Armes (except ≈øwords) they ≈øhall there lay down, and deliver unto the Governour of the next Garri≈øon belonging to the Parliament; the ≈øaid Governour providing for their ≈øafety, during the time of their abode there, where they ≈øhall be a≈ø≈øi≈øted for the procuring Ve≈ø≈øells and Shipping for their tran≈øportation at the accu≈øtomed Rates, and ≈øhall have free Quarter for one and twenty dayes allowed to provide for their pa≈ø≈øage. After which time ≈øhall be expired, the ≈øame Officers and Souldiers paying for their Quarters, ≈øhall have liberty to ≈øtay untill Shipping be provided, and weather ≈øea≈øonable, and that during their ≈øtay, or before, it ≈øhall be
permitted, that any two of them may goe to London, to Treat with any forraigne Emba≈ø≈øadour or Agent, for a Commi≈ø≈øion to be entertained beyond the Seas.

9. That neither the Officers, Souldiers, nor any Per≈øon what≈øoever, in their going out of the City, ≈øhall be reproached, or have any di≈øgracefull ≈øpeeches or affronts offered unto them, or any of their Per≈øons wronged, rifled, ≈øearched, or their goods ≈øeized, or taken away from them, by any per≈øon what≈øoever.

10. That the Governour, Lords, Gentlemen, Clergymen, Chaplaines, Commanders, Officers, and Souldiers comprized in the≈øe Articles, ≈øhall be allowed and a≈ø≈øi≈øted in providing of ≈øufficient Carriages at rea≈øonable rates, to carry away their Bag, Baggage and Goods; & that care be taken by the future Governour of the ≈øaid City, for the curing of ≈øuch ≈øick or wounded Officers and Souldiers, as ≈øhall be left in the City, and that upon recovery, they ≈øhall have Pa≈ø≈øes to repair to their own hou≈øes re≈øpectively.
11. That the Parliament Forces come not into the City untill the Kings Forces be marched out, except one hundred and fifty Foot, and one Troop of Hor≈øe, with their Officers.

12. That no Lords, Knights, Gentlemen, Clergiemen, Chaplaines, (excepting tho≈øe who are by name excepted by Parliament from Pardon and Compo≈øition) Officers, Citizens, and Soldiers, and all other per≈øons comprized in the≈øe Articles, ≈øhall be que≈øtioned or accomptable
for any act pa≈øt by them done, (or by any other done by their procurement) relating unto the unhappy differences betwixt His Maje≈øty and the Parliament, they ≈øubmitting them≈øelves to rea≈øonable and moderate compo≈øition for their e≈øtates, which the Generall Sir Thomas Fairfax ≈øhall really endeavour with the Parliament, that it ≈øhall not exceed two yeares value of any mans reall e≈øtate re≈øpectively; and for per≈øonall, according to the ordinary rule, not exceeding the proportion afore≈øaid. Which compo≈øition being made, they ≈øhall have Indempnity of their per≈øons, and enjoy their e≈øtates, and all other Immunities, without payment of any 5. or 20. part, or any other Taxes or Impo≈øitions, except what ≈øhall be hereafter charged upon them in common with other Subjects of this Kingdome by Authority of Parliament.

13. That all Lords, Knights, Gentlemen, Clergie and Chaplaines excepted in the next precedent Article, ≈øhall have liberty to goe unto any of the Kings Garri≈øons, and to have a ≈øafe Conduct for them≈øelves and ≈øervants, to goe unto the Parliament, to obtain their Compo≈øition for their E≈øtates, and Indempnity for their per≈øons, which (though it prove ineffectuall) yet neverthele≈ø≈øe they ≈øhall have foure months time next after the date of the≈øe Articles to endeavour their peace, or to goe beyond the Seas, and ≈øhall have pa≈ø≈øes for that purpo≈øe.

14. That all Hor≈øes, Armes, Money, and other goods what≈øoever, taken as lawfull prize of War, before, or during the Seige now in the City, be continued in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the pre≈øent po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øour.

15. That all Officers, Gentlemen, Citizens, Inhabitants, Clergymen, Chaplains, Souldiers, and all other per≈øons within the City, during the time of the making their Compo≈øitions, ≈øhall have free liberty, either to inhabit within the ≈øame City, or ≈øhall have free liberty at any time to depart with their Families, Goods and E≈øtates, unto any part of the Kingdome in the Parliaments Quarters, and before Compo≈øition made, the Merchants and Trade≈ømen to enjoy their Merchandizing and Trades. And after Compo≈øitions made, all others now prohibited by Ordinance of Parliament, to enjoy and exerci≈øe their profe≈ø≈øions, or goe beyond the Seas. And that they, and every of them, ≈øhall have power to di≈øpo≈øe and ≈øell to their own u≈øes, either by them≈øelves or others, what≈øoever part of their Goods or E≈øtates, they ≈øhall not carry or convey away with them; and all Inhabitants which did inhabit within the City, within ≈øeven moneths pa≈øt, having made their Compo≈øitions as above≈øaid, ≈øhall enjoy the benefit of this, and of the 12. and 22. Articles.

16. That all Charters, Cu≈øtomes, Priviledges, Franchi≈øes, Liberties, Lands, E≈øtates, Goods and Depts of the Major, Aldermen, Bayliffes, Comminalty, as a Corporation, and all Corporations of the ≈øaid City ≈øhall be enjoyed by them: And that the Ancient Government thereof, remaine as formerly.

17. That if any per≈øons, or Inhabitants which are comprized within the≈øe Articles, ≈øhall break any of them, that ≈øuch breach ≈øhall only touch and concerne ≈øuch per≈øons, and they, to make ≈øuch ≈øatisfaction for the ≈øame, as the cau≈øe ≈øhall require.

18. That all per≈øons comprized within the≈øe Articles, ≈øhall have upon reque≈øt, a Certificate under the hand of his Excellency Sir Thomas Fairfax, or the future Governour of that City, that ≈øuch per≈øons were in the City, at the time of the ≈øurrendring thereof, and are to have the benefit of the≈øe Articles.

19. That His Excellency Sir Thomas Fairfax, give a≈ø≈øurance, that all Officers and Souldiers in the Parliaments Army, and all other under his Command, ≈øhall duly and exactly ob≈øerve all the≈øe Articles. And if they, or any of them, ≈øhall directly, or indirectly violate or infringe the ≈øame, upon complaint thereof, Ju≈øtice may be done, and reparation made.

20. That the Inhabitants of the City ≈øhall be ea≈øed, & freed from all free quarter and billet of Souldiers, except in ca≈øes of urgent nece≈ø≈øity other then for lodging, and that to be ordered and di≈øpo≈øed by the advice of the Major and his Deputy.

21. That no Oath, Covenant Prote≈øtation or ≈øub≈øcription relating thereunto, ≈øhall be impo≈øed upon any per≈øon what≈øoever comprized within the≈øe Articles, but only ≈øuch as ≈øhall binde all per≈øons afore≈øaid, not to bear Armes again≈øt the Parliament of England, now ≈øitting at We≈øtmin≈øter; nor wilfully doe any Act prejudiciall unto their Affaires, while≈øt they remain in their Quarters, except the per≈øons afore≈øaid, ≈øhall fir≈øt render them≈øelves unto the Parlia. who ≈øhall cau≈øe them to be ≈øecured, if they think fit.

22. That for the further and cleerer under≈øtanding of the precedent Articles: It is hereby declared, that the true meaning of them is, that all per≈øons comprized within the≈øe Articles, ≈øhall quietly and peaceably enjoy all their goods, debts, & moveables, during the ≈øpace of four moneths, next en≈øuing: and be free from all Oaths, Covenants, Prote≈øtations, and have liberty within the time of the ≈øaid four moneths, in ca≈øe they ≈øhall not make their Compo≈øitions with the Parliament, and ≈øhall be re≈øolved to goe beyond the Seas, to di≈øpo≈øe of their ≈øaid goods, debts, and moveables, allowed by the≈øe Articles, and depart the Kingdome, if they think fit, and to have Pa≈ø≈øes for that purpo≈øe, or otherwi≈øe to ≈øtay in the Kingdome.

23. That mount Radford, and the Wards in Saint Thomas Pari≈øh, with the Provi≈øions of War thereunto belonging, be delivered unto his Excellency Sir Thomas Fairfax, or whom he ≈øhall appoint, to receive them in a≈ø≈øurance of the performance of the precedent Articles, to morrow by ≈øix of the clock in the afternoone, being the ninth of April. And that foure ≈øuch Gentlemen or Officers as his Excellencie ≈øhall approve of, ≈øhall be delivered at the ≈øame time as Ho≈øtages for the peformance of the fore-going Articles on the one party. And that at the ≈øame time two Ho≈øtages be delivered unto Sir John Berkley, Knight, and Governour of the City of Exeter, ≈øuch as he ≈øhall approve of, or unto whom he ≈øhall appoint, to receive them in a≈ø≈øurance of the full performance of the Articles granted on the other party.
24. La≈øtly, that the≈øe Articles be ratified and confirmed mutually by his Excellency Sir Thomas Fairfax on the one party, and Sir John Berkley, Knight, Governour of the City on the other patty.

closer.dateline: Given under my hand the 9. day of April. 1646.
closer.signed: J doe ratifie and confirme the Articles above≈øaid, agreed upon by the Commi≈øsioners on my part. FAIRFAX.
Ex' Et concordat cum Original'. H. El≈øynge, Cler. Parl. D. Com.

div.head: Die Mercurii 6. Maii. 1646.
div.p: THe Articles made and agreed upon between Sir Thomas Fairfax, Generall, and Sir Iohn Berkley, Governour of Exeter, upon the Rendition of the ≈øaid City, &c. to his Excellency Sir Tho: Fairfax, were all this day read, and upon the Que≈øtion approved.

closer.signed: H. El≈øynge, Cler. Parl. D. Com.

div.p: Die Jovis 4. Novemb. 1647.

THe Lords and Commons a≈ø≈øembled in Parliament doe approve of the Articles of Exeter, and Order this Approbation be publi≈øhed, to the end all people concerned may take notice thereof. And that the Committees, Iudges, Officers, and other per≈øons concerned therein, doe take notice thereof, and ob≈øerve the ≈øame, any Orders or Ordinances to the contrary notwith≈øtanding.

p.hi: H. El≈øynge, Cler. Parl. D. Com.
